text:
He didn’t move after he shouted at her and paused for a moment. At that same time, another thought hit him, as if it had been waiting to surprise him.

“Why did I go to her just now? I said it was for business; but what business? I had none! I just wanted to tell her I was leaving; but why did I need to do that? Do I love her? No, I pushed her away like a dog. Did I want her to suffer? Oh, how low I’ve become! No, I wanted her tears, I wanted to see her scared, to see how much she hurt! I needed something to hold on to, something to slow me down, a friendly face to see! And I dared to believe in myself, to dream about what I would do! I am a pathetic loser, so pathetic!”

He walked along the canal bank and didn’t have much further to go. But when he reached the bridge, he stopped and took a detour to the Hay Market.

He looked eagerly around, staring at everything but couldn’t focus on anything; everything felt distant. “In a week or a month, I’ll be taken to prison over this bridge. How will I look at the canal then? I want to remember this!” he thought. “Look at this sign! How will I read those letters then? It says ‘Company,’ that’s something to remember. That letter ‘a’—how will I see it again in a month? What will I be feeling and thinking then? … What I’m worried about now seems so unimportant! Of course, it must all be interesting … in its own way … (Ha-ha-ha! What am I thinking?)”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The protagonist reflects on his emotional turmoil and the desperation for connection amidst his impending fate.
